Input.threadtitle: Vectorization lecture - do you need some Parallel Processing example?
Input.posts:
I use vectorized code whenever possible (mostly on Matlab), but not so much on C/C++, Java and Python. I always look at my loops and wonder 'how would it be implemented more efficiently on this particular language?'. Probably, many of you feel the same, and if so, here are some things to think about after watching the lecture. On the video , Andrew Ng shows how to vectorize some code and says there are libraries or packages that handle vectorized code on an efficient way for many of those languages. This is becoming more and more true everyday, but it also makes you wonder if the libraries you use are up-to-date with the best algorithms for each case. And even if you don't know which libraries to use, for some of those languages, the compiler/interpreter can also optimize some of your code if you write it in a proper way to be parallelized/vectorized. But if you aren't sure if some package uses some algorithm, you can always implement it by yourself. This semester, I'm taking Parallel Processing classes and I'm seeing that by myself: 'how to improve performance of some piece of code'. That said, while watching the video, I was expecting to see and hear 'This one code is a vectorized code in . And this other code is the implementation under the hood on of that vectorized code'. I mean, I didn't expect an in depth explanation, just a couple line quotation and maybe a 'you can try implementing your own vectorized code by using some parallelization technique' pointing to some Parallel Processing course, either on Coursera or outside it. I just missed the reference to some 'comprehend the vectorization' approach rather than the 'use the vectorization' one. Well, to finish this monologue, I just want to say that until now the lectures were pretty good (matching my expectations) and that this thread is just to instigate those who like getting deep under the code implementation details and maybe getting people to post some vectorization examples for those who may seek it thereafter. I have some piece of code that I'll post on a separate comment.

This is a Fortran code for educational purposes. The parallelized version uses OpenMP directives. It was taken from my classes on CE-265 - Parallel Processing at ITA. What we see here is just a case where something that would normally get calculated on a loop will now get calculated on several loops separated on multiple processors/cores. The way you operate here is not too diferent from what you do when using GPUs for array operations. Code before parallelization: PROGRAM simple USE omp_lib IMPLICIT NONE INTEGER, PARAMETER :: vSize=1000000000 REAL :: vec(vSize) INTEGER :: i DO i = 1, vSize vec(i) = REAL(i - vSize/2) ** 2 END DO DO i = 1, vSize vec(i) = SQRT(vec(i)) END DO WRITE(*,'(' maximum = ', f9.0,'; minimum =',f9.0)') & MAXVAL(vec), & MINVAL(vec) END PROGRAM simple Code after parallelization: PROGRAM simple USE omp_lib IMPLICIT NONE INTEGER, PARAMETER :: vSize=1000000000 REAL :: vec(vSize), maxTot(0:7), minTot(0:7) INTEGER :: i, this, nThreads !$OMP PARALLEL DO DO i = 1, vSize vec(i) = REAL(i - vSize/2) ** 2 END DO !$OMP PARALLEL DO DO i = 1, vSize vec(i) = SQRT(vec(i)) END DO maxTot = -1.0; minTot = REAL(vSize) ** 2 !$OMP PARALLEL DO PRIVATE(this) DO i = 1, vSize this = OMP_GET_THREAD_NUM() nThreads = OMP_GET_NUM_THREADS() maxTot(this) = MAX(maxTot(this), vec(i)) minTot(this) = MIN(minTot(this), vec(i)) END DO WRITE(*,'(' maximum = ', f12.0,'; minimum =',f12.0)')& MAXVAL(maxTot(0:nThreads-1)), & MINVAL(minTot(0:nThreads-1)) END PROGRAM simple

Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Good point, thanks for the thought. Octave/Matlab are high level languages. Octave in particular uses other libraries to perform matrix manipulations, including ATLAS and/or BLAS. These libraries in turn may or may not use parallelization techniques. It's my understanding that if the facilities are present, each library uses the resources available, so that if you have an NVidia card present then the linear algebra algorithms used will be different than if the card was absent. Octave in particular has a package 'octave-forge-parallel' on my openSUSE resources. I have it installed, but my simple 4-core with onboard graphics probably cannot use a lot of the algos available. One thing for sure, for loops in Octave are inefficient and sometimes horribly so, not in terms of accuracy but in execution time. Vectorization good, for loops bad. One of the challenges of the course is to be able to vectorize if you can, but if it takes more time you can still pass.

Input.threadtitle: Why do we need feature scaling?
Input.posts:
One reason I felt feature scaling might be useful is in visualizing the data; like in a 2D graph I don't want my x dimension to be too large and y dimension to be too small But that advantage is for us so that we can analyse the data properly With respect to code or algorithm I still don't feel any advantage. Andrew Ng in his video has mentioned that ranges of features should be proportional otherwise our gradient descent algorithm will be slow. How it can be? If ranges of features are not proportional (say y dimension too large than x dimension) then corresponding slopes of cost function will be large, so large values will be subtracted from theta's and the no of iterations in gradient descent algorithm will be more or less same as compared to the case with proportional feature ranges If the no of iterations in both cases are same then their running time will also be same. Then how could feature scaling will give an advantage?

Edit: So, normalized data --> rounder cost function contour lines so Gradient Descent takes a more direct path to the minimum resulting in fewer steps and faster convergence. One reason I felt feature scaling might be useful is in visualizing the data; like in a 2D graph I don't want my x dimension to be too large and y dimension to be too small But that advantage is for us so that we can analyse the data properly With respect to code or algorithm I still don't feel any advantage. Andrew Ng in his video has mentioned that ranges of features should be proportional otherwise our gradient descent algorithm will be slow. How it can be? If ranges of features are not proportional (say y dimension too large than x dimension) then corresponding slopes of cost function will be large, so large values will be subtracted from theta's and the no of iterations in gradient descent algorithm will be more or less same as compared to the case with proportional feature ranges If the no of iterations in both cases are same then their running time will also be same. Then how could feature scaling will give an advantage?
Upvotes:
1
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Neelmani, 1) I think one reason was that features with large values compared to others could 'dominate' the optimization such as price vs. square footage. 2) Another is that skewed contour lines cause the gradient * alpha step to head in a direction which isn't pointing as directly towards the minimum vs. the case of normalized data. Edit: So, normalized data --> rounder cost function contour lines so Gradient Descent takes a more direct path to the minimum resulting in fewer steps and faster convergence. (Thank you John Bidwell for your comment below reminding me to restate this yet again.) 3) This thread has more details: https://class.coursera.org/ml-005/forum/thread?thread_id=572

Input.threadtitle: Does feature scaling change the coefficient of regression?
Input.posts:
I understand feature scaling makes computation easier. But, after feature scaling, isn't the coefficient of that feature change? What is the effect? For example, House size, is between 0 and 1,000. We divide it by 1000, it is now between 0 and 1. Wouldn't that increase the coefficient by 1000 times, because we are not changing the response. Now, if size $$X_3$$, is part of a training set, and we leave $$X_1$$ and $$X_2$$ fixed. Wouldn't this distort the actual relationship between the features? Say, size is suppose to take on more 'burden' in the regression, now it is not.
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Hi Colin, yes, scaling one or more features will change the coefficients. You just need to remember to transform those features prior to using the theta vector to make a prediction. If you do this, the trained model should work fine.
